moves.1. d4: My opponent soon had his queen cornered after a few repeated moves with it, I pushed a pawn in a speculative hunt to the queen, but then my opponent blundered and eventually lost his queen, his uncoordinated pieces allowed me to sacrifice my queen to force a promotion in a better position and proceeded to mate his exposed king... forcing his resignation
moves.3... c5 4. d5 d6 5. e4 Bg7 6. h3: I have mores space and black's light squares bishop is out of play but on the other hand his dark squares bishop is in a great diagonal, I must be careful with it at all time
moves.6... Qa5 7. Bd2 Qb6: N we were following the game Belotelov Dmitriy (RUS) - Farago Sandor (HUN), Budapest (Hungary), 1999, 1/2-1/2, but black chose to diverge from it
moves.8... O-O 9. Nf3: develops and adds some control to d4 and e5
moves.9... e6: ?! I have my doubts about this move, at this time, as it weakens d6, although challenges my centre, also black's dark squares arround his king are now also weaker than before e6, black needs a6 to prevent Nb5, so to sum things up black is not better after e6
moves.10. Bd3: continues development and add another defender to e4 freeing both my knight and my queen to other tasks
moves.10... exd5 11. cxd5: I prefer an asymmetric structure for lesser chances of drawing, My assessment of this position as equal, although I have more space, black has a great outpost on d4 in case it can be occupied, a hard task due to my pawns set-up, Black needs Na6-c7-b5-d4 to do it, also his dark squares bishop has an open diagonal almost free, but on the other hand the light squares bishop is a bit out of play, it might even became exchanged, white has some piece play, and the initiative, plus a promising e5 pawn break, a king side pawn storm, or a minority attack on the queen's wing
moves.11... Na6 12. a3: denying black's knight the access to b4, the idea now is to play Na4 to remove the queen from the defence of the knight and then maybe Bxa6 to disrupt black's pawn structure
moves.13. O-O Rac8 14. Be3: pinning c5 to avoid black's temptation to push it foreword
moves.14... Qa5: removes the pin so maybe that push b4 was black's idea
moves.15. Qe2: threatening to get the knight and disrupting black's pawn structure when black recaptures
moves.15... Nc7: ? blocks the queen, and allows some tactics
moves.16. b4 cxb4 17. axb4 Qxb4 18. Rxa7: now if Qxc3 white has Bd4 attacking the queen, Queen moves to the b column, and Rb1 wins it
moves.19. Na2: to remove the knight from danger with tempo
moves.19... Qb3: ? better was Ra3 or Ra4, the played move allows white to get his f rook to the b column with tempo
moves.20. Rb1 Qa3 21. Rbxb7: doubles rooks on the 7th rank, a promising strategic theme
moves.21... Rca8 22. Bxa6: wining some material, black left hanging
moves.22... Rxa7 23. Rxa7: and now threatens Bc4 wining the queen
moves.24. Bb5: the bishop is pinned so is captured by this simple tactics
moves.25. Qxb5: and the queen is finally trapped
moves.25... Qxa7 26. Bxa7 Nxe4 27. Bd4: being a piece and Q vs R up, now I'll try to exchange as many pieces as I can
moves.27... f6 28. Qd7: to get to e7 threatening Ne4 and d6
moves.28... Kh8 29. Qe7: now the knight is going to be exchanged anyway
moves.29... Nc5 30. Bxc5: and I'll get the d pawn as well, and then I'll regroup my knights so they can be easily defended

moves.33... Bf8 34. Nc6: blocks the c column and protects the promotion square, while threatening Ne7

moves.35. Kh2 Rd1 36. Nfd4: blocks the rook of the d8 promotion square
moves.36... Rd2 37. d7: !! and now sacrifices the queen to promote with check
moves.37... Bxc5 38. d8=Q+ Kh7 39. Qd7+: now black can't avoid mate, it's just a question of how... my moves are Qd7+ Qe8+ (or QxBe7+ Qf8 Ne6) Ne6+ and mate can only be delayed by giving up pieces
